data.title: Created Header file for net.cpp
data.body:
Added a net.h file for net.cpp to make the class useful from other parts of the engine.

Converted these ConsoleFunction to DefineEngineFunction
-removeTaggedString
-addTaggedString
-getTaggedString

data.title: Added header file and converted ConsoleFunction to DefineEngineFunction
data.body:
I added a header file for Net.CPP and converted the legacy ConsoleFunctions to DefineEngineFunctions.

I also converted these to DefineEngineFunction:
-commandToServer 
-commandToClient
-DefineEngineFunction
-addTaggedString
-removeTaggedString
-getTaggedString

I left the following as ConsoleFunction
-buildTaggedString

data.title: Update player.cpp
data.body: Adds check to stop the player from being able to jump or sprint while crouching under an object.

data.title: Trigger a terrain signal when its transform is changed
data.body: This will cause GroundCover and DecalRoad objects to be updated/regenerated when the terrain's position or rotation is changed.

data.title: Fixed GroundCover placement on rotated TerrainBlocks
data.body: Fixed Issue #330 by transforming the billboard generation point into the terrain's local coordinate system. This accounts for the terrain's full transform, not just its position.

data.title: Development change cloudlayer coverage in script
data.body:
With this addition it is possible to change the coverage of a cloudlayer object in script.

Usage in script:

MyCloudLayerObj.ChangeCoverage(%newCoverageValue);

Where:
MyCloudLayerObj: name of the Cloudlayer object.
%newCoverageValue: the new value for the coverage.

data.title: Cloudlayer coverage change from within script
data.body: This addition enables you to change the coverage of a cloudlayer object in script.

data.title: Cloudlayer coverage change from within script
data.body: These addition to the cloudlayer class enables you to change the coverage value of the cloudlayer object in script.

data.title: Resolution for ap-hang with high-frequency weaponstate changes (IE: AI n...
data.body: ...on-tick descision forks). see also: http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/134036

data.title: Objects set to be hidden in World Editor, show up always the game starts
data.body:
Hello,

I would like to report a possible bug with o T3D MIT.

In short, there are two issues happening either T3D MIT 2.0 or 3.0: 

A) Object set to be hidden, show up always the game starts even if  you ran the "DeleteCachedDTSs.bat" previously after have  saved your level and quit before launch the game level once again. 

B) In the World Editor hidden objects, remain hidden after the first try to uncheck its option hidden in Scene Inspector. I mean after you uncheck the option "hidden"  in the Scene Inspector, however, the object does not appear in the scene as supposed to be.

I did a short video showing the problem in action, and you might see it in the  following link below:

(This video it has been removed, by post's author Joao Sousa)

Greetings,

data.title: mesh names in, Scene tree, Library, meshes, error
data.body:
Mesh names in Scene tree, Library, meshes if they have a space in the filename display wrong.

to see this bug, rename any dts or collada with a space in the name, then go to Scene tree, Library, meshes, (wherever its located)

you will see its also in a folder called whatever the name was before the space.

Its caused by the script replacing all "/"'s as spaces, then striping the words out.
It's fixed by replacing any spaces in the filename with a placeholder character then replacing the placeholder with a space as soon as the words have been striped out.

I have posted this as a resource (although its gone into blogs) with this simple fix.
http://www.garagegames.com/community/blogs/view/22295

data.title: Soldier has no walk triggers rendering footstep sounds in the UI useless
data.body:
The GG Soldier has no walk triggers rendering footstep sounds in the UI useless

Also when trying to add these to 'run' etc - you can't as they are based on the source ambient animation and it refuses to let you add a trigger to it 

You can get around it by manually setting the run animation to frames 0 - 20, add the trigger then set the frames back to 1510-1530

So two issues here 
1) soldier has no triggers for footsteps
2) animation UI in shape editor cannot add triggers to animations calling a source

data.title: Holes in Terrain still collide with the player
data.body:
Between 2.0 and 3.0 the issue of terrain holes blocking the player has returned (this was originally fixed in 1.2) 

Simply make a hole in a default scene and it will still be walkable.

It does not block rain effects however.

data.title: 3.0 broke my pick at cursor function.
Using LF (\n) instead of CRLF (\r\n) causes some parsing errors.

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.title: GameBase WhiteOut and DamageFlash defaults
data.body:
GameBase has its WhiteOut and DamageFlash values default to being active which can cause problems with derived classes.  These defaults will cause the screen to be a solid colour when using a derived class that is a GameConnection control object (based on current project templates).

The solution is to have these default to off so any derived class doesn't need to take care of these by themselves.  Modify https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/master/Engine/source/T3D/gameBase/gameBase.h lines 412 and 413 so the getDamageFlash() and getWhiteOut() return 0.0f instead of 1.0f.

data.title: Clean up SFXSources in Player class
data.body: mMoveBubbleSound and mWaterBreathSound were not being deleted properly

data.title: Frozen rigidshapes still generating collisionsets
data.body:
in void RigidShape::processTick(const Move\* move)

updateWorkingCollisionSet is called reguardless of the capacity of a rigidshape to move out of a collision state, meaning when freezesim is used for a rigidshape penetrating another object, it'll keep parsing that every tick.

quickhack reslution was just to tack on

 if(!mDisableMove) updateWorkingCollisionSet(getCollisionMask());

but it wouldn't surprise if there are a few additional gotchas lurking.

data.title: Clean up SFXSources in Player class
data.body: mMoveBubbleSound and mWaterBreathSound weren't being deleted properly

data.title: Projectiles Warping From "0 0 0"
data.body:
I do not know if its just me or... what but i have been noticing projectiles warping from "0 0 0" to muzzle point. 

Steps to recreate this
Note this is using master branch T3D MIT 3.0 

Start by setting a projectile shape, preferably a large one to make it easier to see(i used the teleport pad) 

Then give your self some lag, (i do see the same thing at very low pings but it seems to start once you get some lag or at random)

Start with 500 then try switching it back to 0, it seems to still happen once it has started  
%client.setSimulatedNetParams(0,500);

Next load up empty room, switch to third person and fire
Be sure to move off from the spawn point because that is were position "0 0 0" is

You should start see projectiles warping from 0 0 0 to muzzle point then continuing on like normal

data.title: Console Logger is not Thread Safe
data.body:
I bumped into an issue with the console logger in a project. If we have the following situation:

Thread 1: Con::printf("One");
Thread 2: Con::printf("Two");
Thread 3: Con::printf("Three");

Usually you'd expect the following to be sent through to the consumers, in whatever order the threads manage to call the consumer:

```
One
Two
Three
```

Depending on the timing of these threads you may get the following sent to the consumers:

```
One
Three
```

In console.cpp we have:

```
static void _printf(ConsoleLogEntry::Level level, ConsoleLogEntry::Type type, const char* fmt, va_list argptr)
{
   if (!active)
       return;
   Con::active = false; 
```

Essentially the "active" check is just a check to prevent a recursion later on in the code. What is happening is since there is no synchronization in _printf, Thread 1 may set active to true causing Thread 2 to ignore the print, while Thread 3 may find active is false again as Thread 1 has finished printing the entry.

If you have the log buffer enabled or the console, you'll likely get a crash as yet again there is no synchronization whatsoever when pushing the log entry to the console log.

In my case since I don't use any of the console stuff (just the consumer list) I solved the issue by just having a lock on the consumer, but I figured maybe a better solution is needed for Torque3D...

data.title: castRay() from inside geometry has different behaviors
data.body:
I've been relying (for better or worse) on the fact that SceneContainer::castRay() used to return true, and set rayInfo.t = 0 (as if it hit something immediately) when ray-casting from inside a .dif interior to some point outside.

In T3D 3.0 interiors are history, and I've noticed that castRay() has totally different behavior for TSStatics. It returns differently based on the TSStatic collisionType:
- Bounds = returns true, rayInfo.t = 0 (same old .dif behavior)
- Collision Mesh = returns false, regardless of type (Box, Capsule, Convex, Mesh etc.)
- None = returns false (obviously)
- Visible Mesh = returns false

Terrain has yet a third behavior. castRay() returns true and sets rayInfo.t as if the ray collided with the backside of the terrain on its way out (ex. 0.6189).

So... which should it be? Can we get consistent behavior across all types? What's the correct way to test a point for inside / outside collision geometry?

data.title: ai poses
data.body: Poses for Aiplayer.

data.title: Let projectiles collide with objects without being armed.
data.body:
With this pull request, projectiles will be able to collide with objects before they have been armed, but wont explode before they have been armed.
Old behaviour is achievable by adding an %this::explode in the onCollision callback, or simply setting a proper arming delay.
Change discussed [here](http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/134064/1#comment_form)

data.title: Changed mASin to mSin in mEaseOutElastic
data.body:
Elastic ease used an arcsinus function where it should have used a sinus
function.

Oh yeah just for the record, for verification that it should have been a sinus and not an archsinus function, read [line 522](https://github.com/lukaspj/Torque3D/blob/96c3b89f66c58abf0f13935b80263cebb1b0cd29/Engine/source/math/mEase.h#L522)

Remake of #200 .

data.title: AiPlayer Poses
data.body: Code to make AiPlayer use poses. Desired pose is now stored in variable mAiPose. Poses are changed via script getAIPose()/setAiPose(pose). AiPlayer animation network fix called via packing/unpacking and reforcing pose.

data.title: Don't require ClientMissionCleanup to exist
data.body: Lukas Joergensen [noticed](http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/134056/1#comment-844077) that ParticleEmitter requires a SimGroup called ClientMissionCleanup to be present or it will have a tantrum. This seems like bad practise.

data.title: Do not require ClientMissionCleanup to exist
data.body: Lukas Joergensen [noticed](http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/134056/1#comment-844077) that ParticleEmitter requires a SimGroup called ClientMissionCleanup to be present or it will have a tantrum. This seems like bad practise.

data.title: Theora texture for cloned material fix
data.body:
When a TSShapeInstance makes a copy of its own materials through
cloneMaterialList() (such as done with client side ShapeBase objects),
the reference to a named diffuse render target was being lost.  This
affected using a TheoraTextureObject on a ShapeBase derived object
(StaticShape, etc.).
